text: it's been a week when Islamic state
seemed to be winning hands-down
capturing Palmyra in Syria and Ramadi
across the border in Iraq in Ramadi in
particular the Iraqi army scarcely
seemed to put up a fight they just ran
for it in America the Defense Secretary
Ashton Carter went on one of the
political chat shows today and was
scathing about the Iraqis thank you his
remarks clearly annoyed the iraqi prime
minister haider al-abadi as I found when
I went to see him as a positively
insulting isn't it I'm surprised why he
said that I mean he was very supportive
of me like I'm sure is he was fed about
he was fed with the wrong information
nevertheless Ramadi was a disaster
wasn't it it makes my heart bleed
because we lost Ramadi but can it surely
assure you we can bring it back soon you
say soon what are we talking about
months
no no I'm talking about days now if the
Iraqi government does recapture Ramadi
it can't come soon enough for these
people some of the tens of thousands
who've been escaping across the busy
bee's bridge over the river Euphrates
desperate to get away from the Islamic
state fighters who are holding Ramadi
now it's boiling hot well over 40
degrees centigrade this little boys been
here for three days now just want to go
home he says these people are Sunnis and
they haven't had much reason to love the
Shia part of Iraq's population yet a
group of Shia politicians has turned up
to see if they can help and they brought
food and water with them to help the
refugees on their way all these people
feel they've been badly let down by
their army and their government
we'll soon find out if Prime Minister
Abadi is right when he says he'd get
Ramadi back within days John Simpson BBC
News Baghdad
